message_1: Consider the first-order language with a single binary relation symbol $<$, which we use to express a linear ordering. Let $\phi$ be the first-order formula that says "there are at least $n$ distinct elements", where $n$ is a positive integer. Write down a formula $\psi$ such that any linearly ordered set of size at least $n+1$ satisfies $\psi$, but every linear ordering of size $n$ or smaller fails to satisfy $\psi$.
message_2:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. We can define the first-order formula $\phi$ as follows:

$$
\phi := \exists x_1 \exists x_2 \cdots \exists x_n \bigwedge_{1 \leq i < j \leq n} (x_i < x_j \lor x_j < x_i) \land \bigwedge_{1 \leq i \neq j \leq n} (x_i \neq x_j)
$$

Now, we want to define a formula $\psi$ such that any linearly ordered set of size at least $n+1$ satisfies $\psi$, but every linear ordering of size $n$ or smaller fails to satisfy $\psi$. We can define $\psi$ as follows:

$$
\psi := \exists x_1 \exists x_2 \cdots \exists x_{n+1} \bigwedge_{1 \leq i < j \leq n+1} (x_i < x_j \lor x_j < x_i) \land \bigwedge_{1 \leq i \neq j \leq n+1} (x_i \neq x_j)
$$

The formula $\psi$ states that there exist $n+1$ distinct elements that are linearly ordered. Any linearly ordered set of size at least $n+1$ will satisfy $\psi$, as it will have at least $n+1$ distinct elements that can be ordered. However, every linear ordering of size $n$ or smaller will fail to satisfy $\psi$, as it will not have enough distinct elements to satisfy the existence quantifiers in $\psi$.
